t: Job 11
Zophar Urges Job to Repent
Then*p Zophar the Naamathite answered and said:
“Should*pn not the multitude of words be answered? And*ld should a man full of talk be vindicated?
Should*ld your empty talk make men hold their peace? And*ld when you mock, should no one rebuke you?
For*ld you have said, ‘My*ld doctrine is*i pure, And*ld I am clean in your eyes.’
But*ld oh, that God would speak, And*ld open His lips against you,
That*ld He would show you the secrets of wisdom! For*ld they*i would*i double your*i prudence. Know*ld therefore that God exacts from you Less*ild than your iniquity deserves.*i
“Can*ln you search out the deep things of God? Can*ld you find out the limits of the Almighty?
They*ild are*i higher than heaven— what can you do? Deeper*ld than Sheol— what can you know?
Their*ld measure is*i longer than the earth And*ld broader than the sea.
“If*ln He passes by, imprisons, and gathers to*i judgment,*i Then*ld who can hinder Him?
For*ld He knows deceitful men; He*ld sees wickedness also. Will*ld He not then consider it?*i
For*ld an empty-headed man will be wise, When*ld a wild donkey’s colt is born a man.
“If*ln you would prepare your heart, And*ld stretch out your hands toward Him;
If*ld iniquity were*i in your hand, and*i you*i put it far away, And*ld would not let wickedness dwell in your tents;
Then*ld surely you could lift up your face without spot; Yes,*ld you could be steadfast, and not fear;
Because*ld you would forget your*i misery, And*ld remember it*i as waters that*i have*i passed away,
And*ld your*i life would be brighter than noonday. Though*ild you were dark, you would be like the morning.
And*ld you would be secure, because there is hope; Yes,*ld you would dig around*i you,*i and*i take your rest in safety.
You*ld would also lie down, and no one would make you*i afraid; Yes,*ild many would court your favor.
But*ld the eyes of the wicked will fail, And*ld they shall not escape, And*ld their hope—loss of life!”
